entry.title: Hide dropdown from Value help annotation
entry.content:
Hello all,

I have a Fiori Elements V4 List Report app with a filterbar and a table. Some fields in the filterbar are annotated to display a value help:

myField @(
        Common.ValueList : {
            $Type : 'Common.ValueListType',
            CollectionPath : 'S4ProjectionEntity',
            SearchSupported: false,
            Parameters : [
                {
                    $Type : 'Common.ValueListParameterInOut',
                    LocalDataProperty : ID,
                    ValueListProperty : 'ID',
                }
            ],
        },
        Common.ValueListWithFixedValues : false,
    )

 I have SearchSupported: false because the CollectionPath is a projection entity from S4 and it is V2, so it does not support $search queries.

This is fine, but Fiori Elements creates a dropdown in the input field that does nothing because the Search is disabled:

Is there any way to remove this dropdown but keeping the value help?
Thanks in advance.

entry.title: RAP event - Additional save > Raise Event > INSERT generates shortdump
entry.content:
Whenever the user calls an OData service, I need to save the data to a table and immediately trigger additional actions. In my case, the preparing and printing of a custom form based on the saved data. In the current setup this generates a shortdump.

To get this to work, I'm using the "with additional save" option within the behavior definition. This provides me with the 'save_modified' method to handle my additional save. If I simply perform an INSERT there, the record is inserted into the database without issue.

However, to properly decouple the process, I raise an entity event 'created', which is defined in the behavior definition.

METHOD save_modified.
    data lt_header type table for event zlp_os_i_del_hdr\\Header~created.
    lt_header = corresponding #( create-header ).
    RAISE ENTITY EVENT ZLP_OS_I_DEL_Hdr\\Header~created from lt_header.
ENDMETHOD.

This event is handled by a separate class.

METHODS:
  consume_created FOR ENTITY EVENT created_instances FOR Header~created.

method consume_created.
  " INSERT here results in shortdump

  loop at created_instances into data(ls_created).
    zlp_os_cl_delivery=>print_label( ls_created-HeaderGuid ).
  endloop.
endmethod.

Normally, in this method, the label is prepared and placed in a print queue. That last step is done using a standard SAP class, which eventually performs an INSERT.

cl_print_queue_utils=>create_queue_item_by_data(
  iv_qname            = lv_printer
  iv_print_data       = lv_pdf
  iv_name_of_main_doc = |Label date/time|
  iv_number_of_copies = 1
).

In case I perform my INSERT there, the system dumps. 

Execution takes place in a transactional context: A "PHASE <modify>" call is
active with "ZLP_OS_BROKER_DELIVERY". The current statement "INSERT <dbtab>" is therefore forbidden.

I was under the impression that the additional save would prevent this from happening. But it seems the event creates a new RAP phase, in which I still can't INSERT anything.

Am I going about this the wrong way? Thanks in advance for the help üôÇ

---

Apologies for the Label, the 'Labels' box only accepts the proposed 'GenAI Assisted Content' although this has nothing to do with the subject ü§î won't let me post without labels, so it is what it is.

entry.title: Re: Activity type confirmation in SAP S/4HANA Public Clou...
entry.content:
Hello @Francesco_Spaggiari1 

Thank you for your question.

Please review these references for more details:

Fulfillment by Percentage of Completion, Review Percentage of Completion, Activity Types: Plan Quantities,

Revenue Recognition Methods for Customer Projects

Blog: How integrated Project Cost and Revenue Planning helps to keep your promises to clients

To summarise, the clean-core approach in public cloud, ensures that Customer Projects automatically update planned costs whenever you create actual postings with an activity type that is not in the work package plan. You cannot disable this in public cloud due to its clean-core principle.

Because of this, any actual time posting that introduces a new activity type will cause the system to increase planned cost, even in a fixed price contract. The idea behind it is to maintain plan vs actual consistency for revenue recognition.

The provided recommendation to prevent this from happening is to ensure that all activity types that may be posted are included in the work package plan even if it has 0 quantity. You may consider as an alternative, to post time with the planned activity type and use internal costing adjustments if need be.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAC date filters
entry.content:
A challenge that we're having is that we'd like to simplify how report consumers can apply date filters in our dashboards.  
We are using an SAC analytic model with acquired data. 
 
What we ideally would like to do:
  1. Give the end user the ability to have a date range filter as a Story filter.  
  2. Have that date filter work for metrics (1) that are logical to count over a date range (easy) and (2) other metrics that only expect a single month (and will crash if they don't receive a single month).  The metric that crashes uses the RESTRICT function to calculate a rolling-12 month count in a numeric point widget. 
  3. We'd like to set the default date filter end date to be the last completed refresh date, which we can access in our Modeler data.  The default date filter start date would then be set to [end date - 24 months]. 
We've accomplished some of the above (point 3) with some page-level scripting and page filters but the holy grail here is a Story filter so users wouldn't need to change a page filter on each page. 
 
Does anyone have some creative thoughts on how to do this? 
 
 Thanks!

entry.title: Re: RAP event - Additional save > Raise Event > INSERT ge...
entry.content:
Hi, 

I believe what you might be missing is the cl_abap_tx=>save( ) to tell the runtime that this execution is happening within the SAVE-phase? In case you understand german, this part or maybe the entire webinar might be helpful: https://youtu.be/K8YctiZ0LNI

I didn't do that much with the event-ing yet myself so I might be wrong. üôÇ

But it sounds about right, quoting the docs: 

  • The transactional phases are implicitly set when RAP business events are consumed locally. This means that RAP event handler methods are started in the modify phase when called. If you want to implement database modifications in RAP event handler method implementations, you must explicitly activate the save phase to avoid causing errors detected by the controlled SAP LUW.

hth.

~Marco

entry.title: Re: How to find the Class with Material Number (MATNR) or...
entry.content:
How the linkage works would be

Material master (MARA/MARC) A KMAT material is flagged as configurable (MARA-KMAT = 'X'). The material is assigned to a class of type 300 in table KLAH (class header) and KSSK (object‚Äìclass assignment). ‚Üí For KMAT, the object number in KSSK is not the material number directly, but the internal object number (OBJEK).

Configuration object (CUOBJ) When you create a sales order with a KMAT, the system generates a configuration instance (CUOBJ in VBAP). This CUOBJ points to the instance in table INOB (object dependencies). INOB links the CUOBJ to the object number (OBJEK) used in classification.

Characteristics values (AUSP) If values are assigned, they are stored in AUSP. But since you said no values are yet assigned, you won‚Äôt see entries there.

So the linkage of tables would be

  • From VBAP, take MATNR and CUOBJ.
  • Use INOB with CUOBJ ‚Üí get OBJEK.
  • Use KSSK with OBJEK and KLART = 300 ‚Üí get the class assignments.
  • Use KLAH with CLASS and KLART = 300 ‚Üí get the class header (name, description).
  • If you need characteristics definitions, use CABN (characteristics) and CAWN (characteristic values).

entry.title: Re: Linking Outgoing Check Information to Journal Entry I...
entry.content:
Good day @Oliver231 

Thank you for your question.

Please review these references for more details:

Configuration of Adobe Document Services, Journal Entries, Manage Outgoing Checks

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_COMMERCE_INTEGRATIONS/8ce6157b995e418093b6e5410bcd74b2/5542577fe23f439b8e60d904fa2e1fb0.html?locale=en-US

In public cloud, filling or extending the Journal Entry XML data provider with additional fields such as the check number is not permitted due to the systems clean-core principle. The XML for both Ledger View and Entry View is strictly controlled and cannot be enriched when you use Custom Fields, extensibility or BAdIs. The reason is that the check number is not part of the accounting document itself and thereby not enabling the Journal Entry to display it.

That means, adhering to the clean-core solution of placing the check number into a field that is part of the FI document is the best practice. That will enable the field appear in the Journal Entry PDF. Alternatively, you can print the check directly in the Manage Outgoing Checks or you may consider building a custom BTP-based correspondence if you required additional details.

Below is a step-by-step clean-core approach to take

First step is in the Post Outgoing Payments app, enter vendor, amount, bank data. In the Document Header Text, enter the check number manually.

Second step is to post the check in the Manage Outgoing Checks. Select the check and confirm assignment.

Step 3 is to display the Journal Entry in the Manage Journal Entries App. Open the posted document; you will see the header text with the check number.

Final step is to create correspondence in PDF. Your check number will appear in the header text since it is part of XML.


Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Building a Smart SAP Service Desk Agent with GenKit and SAP-RPT-1
entry.content:
The Problem: In most SAP organizations, helpdesk teams manually categorize incoming tickets‚Äîassigning the right SAP module, setting priority levels, and flagging escalations. It's repetitive work that slows down response times.

The Solution: Replace this manual triage with an AI agent.

In this guide, I'll show you how to build an agent using Google GenKit and SAP-RPT-1 that automatically analyzes ticket descriptions and predicts module, priority, and escalation status. We'll explore why a simple LLM prompt isn't enough‚Äîand how a tool-based architecture makes this production-ready.

Note: This is a PoC-level implementation. Since most AI + SAP examples focus on CAP integrations, I wanted to explore a different orchestration framework. Let's see what GenKit brings to the table!

Section 1: Your Development Toolkit & Setup

Step 1. Initialize Your Node.js & TypeScript Project

# Create and enter the project directory
mkdir my-genkit-app
cd my-genkit-app

# Initialize a Node.js project
npm init -y

# Set up the source directory and main file
mkdir src
touch src/index.ts

# Install and configure TypeScript
npm install -D typescript tsx
npx tsc --init

Step 2. Install Genkit and Dependencies

# Install Genkit CLI globally
npm install -g genkit-cli

# Install local project dependencies
npm install genkit @genkit-ai/google-genai dotenv

Step 3. Configure Your API Keys

Create .env file in the root directory:

# .env
GEMINI_API_KEY=your-actual-gemini-api-key-here
SAP_RPT_API_KEY=your-actual-rpt-sandbox-api-key-here

Get Your API Keys:

  • Gemini: https://aistudio.google.com/app/apikey
  • SAP-RPT-1: https://rpt.cloud.sap/dashboard

Why GenKit? It is a lightweight, model-agnostic orchestration framework from Google. It's perfect for implementing AI-powered experiences, provides built-in observability, and works across any cloud provider.

A Quick Note on SAP-RPT-1

Before we dive in, I need to give props to whoever at SAP decided to create the RPT-1 sandbox. Seriously‚Äîthis person deserves a promotion.

Historically, the biggest barrier to experimenting with SAP's AI/ML tools has been access. Everything was locked behind enterprise licenses, complex provisioning, or buried in AI Core documentation. You'd spend more time getting credentials than actually building anything.

SAP-RPT-1 flips this. You can log in to the sandbox with SSO or email, get an API key in 1 minute, and start making predictions. 

What is SAP-RPT-1?

RPT-1 (Relational Pre-Trained Transformer) is SAP's first open-source AI model, specifically designed for tabular data prediction. Unlike general-purpose LLMs that are trained on text, RPT-1 understands structured data‚Äîthink spreadsheets, database tables, CSV files.

For our use case (ticket classification), this is perfect. We have historical tickets with columns like SAP_MODULE, PRIORITY, DESCRIPTION, and ESCALATION. RPT-1 can look at patterns in this structured data and predict missing values with surprising accuracy.

The model works by:

  1. Taking your historical data as "context rows" (examples)
  2. Taking your new ticket with [PREDICT] placeholders
  3. Using transformer architecture to understand relationships between columns
  4. Returning predictions based on learned patterns

Think of it as a specialized AI that's really good at one thing: understanding how values in one column relate to values in other columns.

Why Use RPT-1 Instead of Just Gemini?

You might wonder: "Why bother with RPT-1 when Gemini can read tables too?" Valid question. Here's why:

  1. Token Efficiency: RPT-1 is designed for this. You're not burning tokens on JSON formatting and structural overhead.
  2. Specialized Training: It's trained on relational data patterns, not just general text.
  3. Consistent Predictions: For tabular data, RPT-1 gives more consistent, pattern-based results than trying to prompt-engineer a general LLM.

In practice, we'll see that Gemini + RPT-1 as a tool beats Gemini-only approaches by a factor of 36x in token efficiency while improving accuracy.

Section 2: The Journey to an Intelligent Agent (in 3 Attempts)

Quick Note on GenKit Flows

Before we start, a quick word on GenKit's core concept: Flows.

A Flow is a structured AI action with defined input/output schemas. You specify what goes in and what should come out, and GenKit handles the rest. This gives you type-safety, built-in UI for testing, and observability out of the box.

Basic structure:

export const myFlow = ai.defineFlow(
  {
    name: 'FlowName',
    inputSchema: z.object({ ... }),
    outputSchema: z.object({ ... }),
  },
  async (input) => {
    // Your logic here
    return output;
  }
);

That's all you need to know for now. Let's build.

Step 4. Attempt 1: The "Naive" LLM-Only Flow

File: src/index.ts

// src/index.ts - Attempt 1: Naive LLM-only approach
import { genkit, z } from 'genkit';
import * as dotenv from 'dotenv';
import { googleAI } from '@genkit-ai/google-genai';

dotenv.config();

const ai = genkit({
  plugins: [googleAI()],
  model: googleAI.model('gemini-2.5-flash', { temperature: 0.8 }),
});

// Input schema
const TicketInputSchema = z.object({
  description: z.string().describe('Ticket description'),
});

// Output schema
const TicketSchema = z.object({
  description: z.string(),
  sapModule: z.enum([
    "FI", "CO", "MM", "SD", "PP", "WM", "EWM", 
    "HCM", "BW", "CRM", "PM", "QM", "BASIS", 
    "SECURITY", "ADMIN"
  ]),
  priority: z.enum(["Critical", "High", "Medium", "Low"]),
  needEscalation: z.boolean(),
});

// Define the AI Flow
export const ticketPredictFlow = ai.defineFlow(
  {
    name: 'TicketPredictFlow',
    inputSchema: TicketInputSchema,
    outputSchema: TicketSchema,
  },
  async (input) => {
    const prompt = `Act as Service Desk expert.
Based on ${input.description} predict output schema fields (SAP Module, Priority).
If we need to act quickly raise escalation flag.`;

    const { output } = await ai.generate({
      prompt,
      output: { schema: TicketSchema },
    });

    if (!output) throw new Error('Failed to predict');
    return output;
  },
);

async function main() {}
main().catch(console.error);

Run it:

genkit start -- npx tsx --watch src/index.ts

GenKit comes with a built-in developer UI where you can test flows, debug tool calls, and trace execution in real-time. Navigate to localhost:4000 in your browser.

Test in Genkit UI:

{"description": "Can't login to the development system"}

Result:

  • Guessed sapModule: "BASIS"
  • Assigned priority: "Critical"

The LLM lacks business context‚Äîit doesn't know that "can't login to DEV" is typically Medium priority, not Critical.

Step 5. Attempt 2: The "Token-Hungry" LLM + History Flow

The next logical step was to provide historical context to the LLM. I generated a 1,000-ticket history.json file to include in the prompt.

But here's something that surprised me: JSON is actually not optimal for LLM prompts.

I know, I know‚ÄîJSON is everywhere, it's the standard for APIs, we use it without thinking. But when you're feeding data into an LLM context window, JSON is incredibly wasteful. All those quotes, brackets, commas, and structural overhead? Those are tokens. And tokens cost money.

Think about it: {"name": "value"} uses way more tokens than just name: value. Multiply that by 1,000 rows of ticket data, and you're burning through your token budget on syntax instead of actual content.

Enter TOON (Token-Oriented Object Notation). It's a format specifically designed for LLM prompts‚Äîstrips away JSON's bloat while keeping data readable. The savings? 30-60% fewer tokens for the same data.

For our use case where we're feeding 1,000 historical tickets on every request, this actually matters.

First, install TOON for token optimization:

npm install @toon-format/toon

Create a sample src/history.json file:

[
  {
    "TICKET_ID": "TKT_001",
    "SAP_MODULE": "BASIS",
    "PRIORITY": "Medium",
    "DESCRIPTION": "Cannot login to development system",
    "ESCALATION": false
  },
  {
    "TICKET_ID": "TKT_002",
    "SAP_MODULE": "FI",
    "PRIORITY": "Critical",
    "DESCRIPTION": "Payment posting failed in production",
    "ESCALATION": true
  },
  {
    "TICKET_ID": "TKT_003",
    "SAP_MODULE": "MM",
    "PRIORITY": "Low",
    "DESCRIPTION": "Purchase order print layout issue",
    "ESCALATION": false
  }
]

File: src/index.ts (Updated)

// src/index.ts - Attempt 2: LLM + Historical Context (inefficient)
import { genkit, z } from 'genkit';
import * as dotenv from 'dotenv';
import { googleAI } from '@genkit-ai/google-genai';
import { encode } from '@toon-format/toon';
import historicalDataJson from './history.json' with { type: 'json' };

dotenv.config();

const ai = genkit({
  plugins: [googleAI()],
  model: googleAI.model('gemini-2.5-flash', { temperature: 0.8 }),
});

// Convert historical data to TOON format (saves 30-60% tokens)
const historicalDataToon = encode(historicalDataJson);

const TicketInputSchema = z.object({
  description: z.string().describe('Ticket description'),
});

const TicketSchema = z.object({
  description: z.string(),
  sapModule: z.enum([
    "FI", "CO", "MM", "SD", "PP", "WM", "EWM", 
    "HCM", "BW", "CRM", "PM", "QM", "BASIS", 
    "SECURITY", "ADMIN"
  ]),
  priority: z.enum(["Critical", "High", "Medium", "Low"]),
  needEscalation: z.boolean(),
});

export const ticketPredictFlowWithHistory = ai.defineFlow(
  {
    name: 'TicketPredictFlowWithHistory',
    inputSchema: TicketInputSchema,
    outputSchema: TicketSchema,
  },
  async (input) => {
    const prompt = `Act as Service Desk expert.
    
Historical ticket data (TOON format):
${historicalDataToon}

Based on the historical patterns above and this new ticket description: "${input.description}"
Predict the SAP Module, Priority, and whether escalation is needed.`;

    const { output } = await ai.generate({
      prompt,
      output: { schema: TicketSchema },
    });

    if (!output) throw new Error('Failed to predict');
    return output;
  },
);

async function main() {}
main().catch(console.error);

Result:

‚è±Ô∏è  Time: 12.72 seconds
ü™ô Tokens: 22,993 input tokens

Even with TOON optimization, this approach proved to be highly inefficient. Feeding 1,000 tickets to the LLM on every request is fundamentally the wrong architecture‚Äîno amount of token optimization can fix that. It's slow, expensive, and doesn't scale.

Section 3: The "Right Way" ‚Äî LLM as Orchestrator, SAP-RPT-1 as Tool

After the token disaster in Attempt 2, I had to rethink the architecture. The problem wasn't the prompt‚Äîit was the fundamental approach.

The Key Insight: Separation of Concerns

Instead of making the LLM do everything (understanding context + making predictions), what if we split responsibilities?

  • Gemini (LLM): Acts as the orchestrator‚Äîunderstands the user's request, decides what needs to happen, formats the final response
  • SAP-RPT-1: Acts as the specialist tool‚Äîhandles the actual prediction based on historical patterns

This is analogous to how you'd structure a real team. You don't ask a senior architect to also manually check every ticket priority. The architect decides "we need a priority prediction for this ticket," then delegates to a specialist who has the historical knowledge.

How SAP-RPT-1 API Actually Works

RPT-1 is designed specifically for this pattern. Here's the mental model:

You send a POST request to https://rpt.cloud.sap/api/predict with a body containing:

  1. Context Rows: Your complete historical data (all 1,000 tickets with known values)
  2. Query Row: Your new ticket, but with [PREDICT] placeholders for fields you want the model to fill in

Example query row:

{
  "TICKET_ID": "TKT_NEW",
  "SAP_MODULE": "[PREDICT]",     // ‚Üê RPT-1 will predict this
  "PRIORITY": "[PREDICT]",        // ‚Üê RPT-1 will predict this
  "DESCRIPTION": "Can't login",   // ‚Üê We provide this
  "ESCALATION": "[PREDICT]"       // ‚Üê RPT-1 will predict this
}

The model looks at patterns in your context rows and predicts the missing values. It's like asking: "Given all these examples where Description X correlated with Module Y and Priority Z, what should the values be for this new description?"

Why This Architecture Wins

Compare the two approaches:

Attempt 2 (Bad):

User Request ‚Üí LLM with 1,000 tickets in prompt ‚Üí Prediction
              ‚Üë
        (22,993 tokens, 12.7s, $$$)

Attempt 3 (Good):

User Request ‚Üí LLM decides: "I need a prediction"
            ‚Üí LLM calls RPT-1 tool (sends 1,000 tickets to specialized API)
            ‚Üí RPT-1 returns prediction
            ‚Üí LLM formats response
              ‚Üë
        (639 tokens, 9.3s, $)

The historical data never enters the LLM's context window. It goes directly to the specialized prediction model that was built for this exact job.

GenKit's Role: Tools

GenKit makes this pattern easy through its "Tools" concept. A tool is just a function that:

  1. Has a defined input/output schema
  2. Can be called by the LLM during generation
  3. Returns structured data back to the LLM

When you give the LLM access to tools, it automatically decides when to use them based on the prompt. You'll see this in the GenKit UI trace‚Äîthe LLM literally "thinks": "I need to predict ticket properties, I should call the predictTicket tool."

This is the magic of agentic AI: the LLM becomes a coordinator, not a do-everything oracle.

How to Build the SAP-RPT-1 Tool

Now let's implement this. We'll create a GenKit tool that wraps the RPT-1 API call:

File: src/index.ts (Final Version)

// src/index.ts - Final: LLM Orchestrator + SAP-RPT-1 Tool
import { googleAI } from '@genkit-ai/google-genai';
import { genkit, z } from 'genkit';
import * as dotenv from 'dotenv';

dotenv.config();

const ai = genkit({
  plugins: [googleAI()],
  model: googleAI.model('gemini-2.5-flash', {
    temperature: 0.8,
  }),
});

// ===== SCHEMAS =====
const TicketInputSchema = z.object({
  description: z.string().describe('Ticket description')
});

const TicketSchema = z.object({
  description: z.string(),
  sapModule: z.enum([
    "FI", "CO", "MM", "SD", "PP", "WM", "EWM", 
    "HCM", "BW", "CRM", "PM", "QM", "BASIS", 
    "SECURITY", "ADMIN"
  ]),
  priority: z.enum(["Critical", "High", "Medium", "Low"]),
  needEscalation: z.boolean()
});

// ===== SAP-RPT-1 TOOL =====
export const predictTicketWithSAPRPT1 = ai.defineTool({
  name: 'predictTicket',
  description: 'Predicts SAP service ticket properties using SAP-RPT-1 AI model',
  inputSchema: TicketInputSchema,
  outputSchema: TicketSchema
}, async (input) => {
  try {
    // Load historical data (in production, this could come from a database)
    const historicalDataJson = (await import('./history.json', {
      with: { type: 'json' }
    })).default;

    // Create prediction row with [PREDICT] markers
    const predictionTicket = {
      TICKET_ID: "TKT_PREDICT",
      SAP_MODULE: "[PREDICT]",
      PRIORITY: "[PREDICT]",
      DESCRIPTION: input.description,
      ESCALATION: "[PREDICT]",
    };

    // Build request: historical context + new ticket
    const body = {
      rows: [...historicalDataJson, predictionTicket],
      index_column: "TICKET_ID",
    };

    // Call SAP-RPT-1 API
    const response = await fetch('https://rpt.cloud.sap/api/predict', {
      method: 'POST',
      headers: {
        'Content-Type': 'application/json',
        'Authorization': `Bearer ${process.env.SAP_RPT_API_KEY}`,
      },
      body: JSON.stringify(body)
    });

    if (!response.ok) {
      throw new Error(`SAP-RPT API error: ${response.status} ${response.statusText}`);
    }

    const data = await response.json();
    const prediction = data.prediction.predictions[0];

    // Map RPT-1 response to our schema
    return {
      description: input.description,
      sapModule: prediction.SAP_MODULE[0].prediction,
      priority: prediction.PRIORITY[0].prediction,
      needEscalation: prediction.ESCALATION[0].prediction === "1.0" ? true : false
    };

  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Error calling SAP-RPT API:', error);
    throw new Error(`Failed to get prediction from SAP-RPT: ${error instanceof Error ? error.message : 'Unknown error'}`);
  }
});

// ===== MAIN AGENT FLOW =====
export const serviceTicketAgent = ai.defineFlow(
  {
    name: 'ServiceTicketAgent',
    inputSchema: TicketInputSchema,
    outputSchema: TicketSchema,
  },
  async (input) => {
    const prompt = `Act as Service Desk expert. Analyze ticket description: ${input.description}.
    
Predict and return JSON with:
- SAP Module (FI, CO, MM, SD, etc.)
- Priority (Critical, High, Medium, Low)
- requiresEscalation: true if downtime, data loss, security risk, or critical response needed

Use historical patterns for consistent routing decisions.`;

    // Genkit automatically decides when to call the tool
    const { output } = await ai.generate({
      prompt,
      output: { schema: TicketSchema },
      tools: [predictTicketWithSAPRPT1]
    });

    if (!output) throw new Error('Failed to predict');
    return output;
  },
);


async function main() {

}

main().catch(console.error);

Complete File Structure

my-genkit-app/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.ts          # Main code
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ history.json      # Historical tickets
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .env                  # API keys (don't commit!)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .gitignore           # Add .env here
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ package.json
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ tsconfig.json

Results Comparison

Attempt Time Input Tokens Cost

1: Naive LLM~3s150
2: LLM + History12.7s22,993
3: LLM + RPT-1 Tool9.3s639

Winner: Attempt 3 - 36x more token-efficient than Attempt 2

When This Approach Makes Sense

Use This Architecture When:

  • You have historical tickets for training context
  • Historical data have good quality
  • You need consistent, explainable predictions
  • Token costs matter (high volume environments)

Don't Use This For:

  • One-off tickets without historical patterns
  • Unclear or constantly changing categories
  • Simple keyword-based routing (regex is cheaper!)

Useful Links

  • SAP-RPT-1 Sandbox: https://rpt.cloud.sap/dashboard
  • SAP-RPT-1 GitHub: https://github.com/SAP-samples/sap-rpt-1-oss
  • SAP-RPT-1 Product Page: https://www.sap.com/products/artificial-intelligence/sap-rpt.html
  • GenKit Documentation: https://firebase.google.com/docs/genkit

Found this helpful? Share your thoughts in the comments or connect with me to discuss AI integration.

entry.title: Re: SAPUI5 application in Build Workzone with CAP Applica...
entry.content:
Well i kinda solved the problem by moving the SAPUI5 application to the same repository and structure of the CAP Backend, so this SAPUI5 now looks more like a microfrontend for the CAP application, and from within I can setup the app router to internally forward requests to the CAP backend in xs-app.json, given that the destination in xs-app.json points to a destination that has its URL mapping to the 

~{srv-api/srv-url}, which is the same url of the cap backend. if you check capire samples and pretty much CAP, i'd say 99% of the apps work with this landscape so this might be the way to go.
 
However, I believe that Workzone it should be able to forward requests towards other services by using the managed app Router, but trying to follow the documentation of Build workzone i couldn't make it work.

entry.title: Certified Excellence: How Cognizant Sets the Benchmark for Driving Real SAP Transformation
entry.content:
Our longstanding partner Cognizant sheds light on how it is redefining SAP services for a cloud-first, AI-powered world.

In this interview, Sivakumar Varadananjayan, Assistant Vice President and Delivery Head ‚Äì SAP Cloud & SAP GGM Product and Resources (Global Growth Market) at Cognizant Technology Solutions, shares insights about Cognizant's Path from ERP to AI-Powered, Industry-Focused Innovation. As the leader of Cognizant‚Äôs SAP Certification initiative and its Validation Partner status, Sivakumar also shares his perspective on Cognizant‚Äôs renewed global certifications, the evolution of their SAP certification journey, and how they plan to further expand their SAP competencies to support customers. The conversation was conducted during Cognizant‚Äôs SAP Certification process, together with Christoph Andre, SAP Auditor and Partner Manager, who led the audit at Cognizant, and Hossam Saad, SAP Partner Manager and Cognizant‚Äôs main point of contact.

Sivakumar outlines how they have evolved from traditional ERP implementations to a transformation model centered on automation, intelligence, and industry specificity. He also discusses their role as a RISE with SAP Validated Partner, its commitment to SAP Best Practices, and how cloud migrations are accelerated through clean-core principles and end-to-end governance. With renewed global SAP certifications, expanded security capabilities, and deep DevOps integration, Cognizant positions itself as a pioneer in secure, future-ready SAP transformation. Looking ahead, Sivakumar shares how continued investment in talent, co-innovation, and industry-focused solutions will shape the next chapter of intelligent enterprise modernization.

 

Christoph: Cognizant is globally known for providing SAP-related services. How have you been adapting your services to ever-changing customer needs and technology innovations?

Sivakumar: Adaptability is at the heart of Cognizant‚Äôs SAP strategy. Over the past decade, we‚Äôve transitioned from traditional ERP implementations to cloud-first, AI-enabled, and automation-driven models. Our approach focuses on three pillars:

  • Cloud Enablement: We leverage SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) to deliver scalable, resilient architectures that support rapid innovation and business agility.
  • Intelligent Automation: Through SAP Business AI, Joule Agents, and Cognizant‚Äôs Automation Fabric, we integrate robotic process automation and generative AI into SAP workflows, reducing manual effort and improving accuracy.
  • Customer-Centric Design: We co-innovate with clients using SAP‚Äôs cloud solutions and industry accelerators, ensuring transformation aligns with their business priorities and delivers measurable outcomes.

Innovation is embedded in every stage ‚Äì from RISE with SAP S/4HANA Conversions to AI-powered solutions like SAP-Certified Case Management AI Agent for SAP and Finance4U¬Æ for industry-specific needs. These capabilities enable real-time insights, predictive analytics, and continuous modernization, helping clients thrive in a rapidly changing digital economy.

 

Christoph: Cognizant positions itself as a pioneer in leveraging SAP Business Suite, cloud ERP, and Business AI. How do you tailor your SAP services to address industry-specific challenges, and what role does innovation play?

Sivakumar: Cognizant tailors its SAP services through a deep industry-in-context approach - combining process expertise, data intelligence, and AI-driven automation to address the unique challenges of each sector. Our strategy integrates SAP Business Suite, cloud ERP, and Business AI with domain accelerators, industry templates, and pre-built integration frameworks that shorten time-to-value and enhance business agility.

Innovation is embedded in every stage - from co-innovation with SAP and hyperscale cloud platforms to leveraging SAP Business AI, developing digital twins, and advanced analytics for continuous transformation. This ensures that clients don‚Äôt just modernize their ERP landscape but also unlock new business models, improve decision velocity, and stay future-ready in an AI-enabled economy.

A strong example of this innovation-led, industry-tailored approach is reflected in Cognizant‚Äôs Utegration portfolio for utilities and energy enterprises:

  • Finance4U¬Æ Extended Asset Accounting: Enhances SAP property accounting with regulatory-compliant, utility-specific asset management capabilities.
  • Finance4U¬Æ Regulatory Accounting and Reporting: Streamlines regulated financial reporting, improving data accuracy and audit readiness.
  • Utility4U‚Ñ¢: A RISE with SAP-based cloud accelerator that modernizes and simplifies the utility ERP landscape while embedding industry best practices.
  • MeterData4U¬Æ: Unlocks the value of Advanced Metering Infrastructure (AMI) by integrating and operationalizing meter data within SAP environments.

Together, these offerings demonstrate how Cognizant combines deep domain experience with SAP innovation to deliver measurable outcomes across industries - from operational efficiency to intelligent, data-driven growth.

 

Hossam: As a ‚ÄúRISE with SAP Validated Partner,‚Äù what has been your experience in leading SAP customers‚Äô migration to cloud? How are your services modeled around SAP Best Practices?

Sivakumar: As a RISE with SAP Validated Partner, our experience in leading SAP customers‚Äô migration to the cloud has been extensive and transformative. We have successfully delivered large-scale migrations for global enterprises using SAP‚Äôs validated methodology, ensuring predictable timelines, reduced risks, and accelerated time-to-value. Our approach emphasizes clean core principles with embedded quality gates, supported by SAP Cloud ALM for governance and compliance.

Our services are modelled around SAP Best Practices, integrating SAP‚Äôs ecosystem tools such as Cloud ALM, LeanIX, Signavio, Business Technology Platform (BTP), Joule, and Tricentis Test Automation. This toolchain enables automation, collaboration, and robust governance throughout the migration journey. Additionally, all key roles - Project Managers, Architects, Developers, and Consultants - are SAP-certified and trained on the latest cloud and AI innovations, ensuring customers are positioned for continuous innovation post-migration.

Finally, we focus on delivering customer-centric outcomes by accelerating cloud transformation with minimal disruption and ensuring smooth migration from ECC or on-premise systems to SAP S/4HANA Cloud. By leveraging SAP Best Practices and validated frameworks, we provide transparent, milestone-driven projects that reduce risk and deliver predictable results. Our engagements consistently achieve high satisfaction scores, reflecting our commitment to quality, innovation, and long-term customer success.

 

Christoph: Cognizant recently renewed global certifications for SAP Business Suite and SAP S/4HANA services and achieved its first global certification for SAP security operations. How do your competencies in DevOps, Security, and Business AI add value?

Sivakumar: Cognizant‚Äôs renewed global certifications for SAP Business Suite and SAP S/4HANA services, along with its first global certification for SAP Security Operations, reinforce our ability to deliver secure, agile, and intelligent SAP transformations. These credentials validate our expertise in modernizing SAP landscapes while ensuring compliance and resilience for mission-critical environments.

Our DevOps competency accelerates SAP delivery through automated CI/CD pipelines, enabling rapid release cycles, improved quality, and seamless integration with RISE with SAP and cloud platforms. In parallel, our Security Operations capability provides proactive threat management, robust identity governance, and real-time monitoring - critical for industries with stringent regulatory requirements. Internally, Cognizant leverages a DevOps for a Unified Competency Management model across SAP competencies to bring people, process, and knowledge together around the work we do.

Finally, Business AI brings intelligence into SAP workflows by embedding predictive analytics, generative AI, and automation. This drives faster decision-making, reduces manual effort, and unlocks new business models across sectors. Together, these strengths position Cognizant as a trusted partner for enterprises seeking secure, automated, and AI-powered SAP transformations.

 

Hossam: How has your SAP certification journey evolved - from your first global certification in 2011 to today? What motivated you initially, and how has your approach changed?

Sivakumar: As you have rightly pointed out, Cognizant‚Äôs SAP global certification journey began in 2011, when we became one of the earliest partners to achieve SAP Cloud Certification. At that time, our motivation was clear: to build client confidence, demonstrate market leadership, and align with our vision of driving enterprise modernization through cloud-first strategies. This milestone positioned us ahead of industry trends and validated our ability to deliver secure, scalable SAP solutions.

Since then, our approach has evolved from meeting compliance standards to driving continuous innovation. Today, certifications are part of a broader strategy focused on SAP S/4HANA, SAP BTP, and RISE with SAP, integrating AI, automation, and sustainability into transformation programs. We‚Äôve expanded from core ERP to end-to-end digital solutions, strengthened partnerships with SAP and hyperscale cloud providers, and invested heavily in talent development through role-based certifications. For us, certification is no longer a one-time achievement - it‚Äôs a continuous journey to deliver measurable business outcomes and stay ahead of client needs.

 

Hossam: Looking ahead, how do you plan to grow your SAP competency and services to support customers?

Sivakumar: Cognizant plans to deepen its SAP competency by focusing on next-generation technologies such as SAP Business AI and industry-specific solutions developed and integrated leveraging SAP BTP. We are investing in advanced capabilities around RISE with SAP, SAP BTP, and SAP S/4HANA transformations, ensuring clients can accelerate their cloud journeys with agility and resilience. Our strategy includes embedding AI-driven automation, predictive analytics, and sustainability frameworks into SAP landscapes, enabling customers to unlock new business models and achieve measurable outcomes. These innovations will be supported by strong partnerships with SAP and hyperscale cloud providers to deliver integrated, multi-cloud architectures tailored to client needs.

 

 

Information on the certification program for operations partners and an overview of all certified partners can be found in the SAP Operations Partner Guide.

Visit OPC at SAP.com or on the SAP Partner Portal.

entry.title: Simplifying AWS EC2 with Cloud Connector installation & SAP DP Agent Integration with BTP
entry.content:
Hi Folks,

This blog demonstrates how to create an AWS EC2 instance, configure storage using LVM, install SAP Cloud Connector and Data Provisioning (DP) Agent, and integrate DP agent with SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) trial account. This setup is ideal for learning and proof-of-concept scenarios.

1.        Overview

We are planning to show you end to end AWS server creation along with mount point creation, and installation of SAP DP & Cloud connector installation, and after that we have configured these systems with BTP free trial account.

Aws trial account -- https://aws.amazon.com/free/

BTP trial account -- SAP BTP Cockpit

2.        AWS EC2 instance creation

As per SAP standard we can only choose SUSE & RHEL image.

Key pair is necessary to generate if you want to access EC2 instance via public ip, other wise server will not authenticate you.

Either you can select existing security group or create new SG

Attach disk as per your requirements

EC2 instance created

To download media and upload into the server we have configure S3 bucket.

3.        S3 bucket Creation

Simply goto S3 and create by selecting create button and enter bucket name and leave all the filled as it is.

4.        Attach IAM role to EC2 instance

To connect S3 bucket with EC2 instance we must attached IAM role to EC2 instance.

Role:

Via Attaching this role we are enabling Connection of S3 bucket with EC2 instance.

5.        Creation of file system

We have used LVM for file system creation, LVM (Logical Volume Manager) is a disk management system in Linux that provides a flexible way to manage storage compared to traditional partitions.

 5.1 validate that separate disk is attach or not via lsblk cmd

PV = Bricks

VG = A big wall built with those bricks

LV = Windows or doors cut out of the wall

5.2   created physical volume pvcreate

5.3 Create Volume group VG
  1. Now we created vg (volume group) from the above pv and validated from vgs command.

5.4 Create LV, Logical Volume
  1. Now we have created lv volume as per our filesystem need
  2. Usrsap - /usr/sap ‚Äì sap filesystem

HI @mickaelquesnot,

thank you for the comprehensive post.

However, I would like to make the remark that your comparison between account-based CO-PA and Margin Analysis at the baseline for this post is incorrect. 

The two options existing for CO-PA in SAP S/4HANA are actually:

  • Margin Analysis (formerly called account-based profitability analysis) and
  • Costing-based profitability analysis (which is the one you are referring to in you post).

Thank you and kind regards

entry.title: Re: SAP Community Hobbies Serries: Most weekends, I jump out of airplanes with my friends
entry.content:
@smarchesini - in the US, a typical tandem jump might cost around $250.  Once you obtain a license to jump solo and you have purchased your own 'rig', jumps are typically $25-$30 each. 

People can experience vertigo when jumping, but it is uncommon.  It's a widely-held misconception that you experience "zero gravity" while in freefall.  When jumping from a plane, you won't experience less than about a half a gee. The reason is a bit technical, but - basically - your body experiences a rapid horizontal deceleration.  You are no longer being propelled along by the airplane -- and drag dissipates that initial horizontal "toss".  At the same time, you will accelerate downwards but that acceleration is ultimately limited by drag - which increases dramatically as your vertical velocity builds.  This simulatneous deceleration and acceleration net out to about half a gee at the start of the jump. At some point, you reach "terminal velocity" where your drag equals the pull of gravity -- and - voila - you are back to experiencing "one gee" again - even though you are falling at about 120 miles per hour.

I do not bungee jump or BASE jump.  It might seem ironic, but skydiving is a safety oriented sport.  We always carry a second, reserve parachute. We deploy our main parachute with ample time to deal with uncommon situations.  These similar sports offer no such safety margin - so I consider them beyond my personal acceptable risk envelope.

entry.title: Re: How to find the Class with Material Number (MATNR) or...
entry.content:
Your INOB seems to be not working because of input parameters. When you want to link a material (MATNR) to its classification/configuration:

OBTAB tells you what kind of object it is. For materials, OBTAB = MARA.

OBJEK is the internal object number used in classification tables like KSSK and AUSP. This is the field you join to KSSK (with KLART = 300).

MATNR in INOB is a convenience field ‚Äî it mirrors the material number when OBTAB = MARA. You can use MATNR directly if you want to search by material number. But for classification joins, you should use OBJEK.

entry.title: SAP SuccessFactors HCM: Updated Home Page 2H 2025
entry.content:
The second half of 2025 marks a major milestone for SAP SuccessFactors HCM: the launch of a refreshed, smarter, and more intuitive home page experience. Designed to help employees, managers, and HR administrators work more efficiently, this update streamlines navigation, personalizes content, and makes every interaction smoother.

And before you read further, I‚Äôm sure every SAP SuccessFactors customer is wondering whether this has full parity with the current home page. I‚Äôm happy to say that yes, it does! Perhaps this is a great opportunity for you to review what is working and maybe not working with what you have in your current home page, and include those changes when you roll out this version.

We‚Äôre excited for you to explore the new home page and see just how much easier your day-to-day work can be, with faster navigation, personalized shortcuts, and dynamic content that surfaces the information and tasks you need most. By streamlining actions and tailoring your experience, the updated home page helps you work smarter and stay focused on what matters most!

Smarter, Faster Actions

The updated Quick Actions are designed to anticipate what you need most. Whether it‚Äôs approving time off, updating personal details, or managing team requests, the system automatically surfaces relevant tasks‚Äîsaving time and reducing clicks. And now, these Quick Actions are also available in SAP SuccessFactors Work Zone, extending the HR experience into your broader workspace.

 

 

A Clean, Modern Design

The redesigned layout features a modern look with consistent card design, clearer hierarchy, and a cleaner presentation of information. It‚Äôs easier on the eyes, simpler to navigate, and built for how people work today.

 

 

Dynamic, Personalized Content

Banners and custom cards can bring your home page to life‚Äîperfect for company news, team updates, or leadership messages. Content is dynamic, so each user sees what‚Äôs most relevant to them, keeping the experience focused.

 

 

Tailored to You

With new personalization options, users can customize their home page, save bookmarks, and receive personalized recommendations tailored to their skills and career goals. The new ‚ÄúRequests for Me‚Äù section ensures time-sensitive tasks‚Äîlike approvals or surveys‚Äîare always visible.

 

Consistent on Mobile

The mobile app now mirrors the web experience, offering a seamless transition between devices. A new splash screen, updated navigation, and consolidated task view make it easier than ever to stay productive on the go‚Äîwhether on iOS or Android.

 

Why It Matters

This update isn‚Äôt just a design refresh‚Äîit‚Äôs a more intelligent, role-aware experience that helps people get work done faster and with less effort. You‚Äôll see:

  • Improved productivity through faster task completion.
  • A contextual experience that reduces distractions.
  • Easier customization without complex setup.
  • Flexible rollout options so organizations can adopt at their own pace.

Getting Started

To prepare for rollout, start with early preview and testing in sandbox environments. Map existing content to new cards, identify gaps, and engage your users early. Use in-app guidance with WalkMe for SAP SuccessFactors HCM to make the transition seamless.

Explore the New Experience

The updated SAP SuccessFactors HCM home page is more than a fresh coat of paint‚Äîit‚Äôs a step toward a more personalized, efficient, and engaging HR experience.

Check out the 2H release home page video, with full details here on the new features, so you can empower your teams to get the most out of every interaction.

entry.title: BiWhy ‚Äì Sessions with New Features and Charts Demo
entry.content:
Disclaimer:

BiWhy is available again for FREE to everyone on biwhy.net

 

Sessions do not necessarily reflect concurrency, as they may be stale or inactive. Because of that, new functionality was added to analyze only new users/sessions separately.

BOBJ session overview, analysis, and administration:

  • Overview and analysis:
    • Session/User chart: the lines should run in parallel, ideally close to one another. Divergence usually indicates a problem.
    • Summary Table ‚Äì sessions aggregated by User / Authentication / Client.
      • Simultaneous Sessions ‚Äì high numbers are a sign of a session leak.
      • Unique Sessions ‚Äì how frequently a user logged in with a given method.
      • Max and Avg Duration ‚Äì high values indicate that sessions are not being closed, either explicitly or by timeout, or that there is real activity on those sessions.
    • Detailed Table ‚Äì shows details for each session.
    • Only new users/sessions per minute (configurable).The chart is also available for any BiWhy table.
  • Bucket analysis (here session duration) shows that most sessions last about 60 minutes. This indicates that they are being terminated by timeout, meaning users either do not close reports or explicit session termination on tab/browser close is not working. It also means that most of the sessions we see are idle.
  • The duration line chart visualizes the 60-minute pattern (timeout).
  • Duration Gantt view ‚Äì session dynamics.

 

  • Admin Page:
    • Analysis: It allows you to see live users and sessions in the system, similar to the CMC functionality, but with all analytical features available in BiWhy tables and charts.
    • Administration: It allows you to cancel selected users/sessions. Unlike in the CMC, you can do this in bulk, which is particularly useful when you have a large number of unwanted sessions. For example, VTO scripts often generate test users but fail to clean them up. Instead of waiting for timeouts or restarting the system (which may not be possible if a non-VTO script is generating sessions in a PROD environment), you can simply terminate all of them directly from BiWhy.

You can also see days-old stale sessions that somehow survive system restarts and are not visible in the CMC. They appear to be harmless, but for cleanup purposes, it is a good idea to cancel them as well.

Screenshots:

Session/User chart: the lines should run in parallel, ideally close to one another. Divergence usually indicates a problem that causes a session leak.

Detailed Table ‚Äì shows details for each session.

Summary Table ‚Äì sessions aggregated by User / Authentication / Client.

  • Simultaneous Sessions ‚Äì high numbers are a sign of a session leak.
  • Unique Sessions ‚Äì how frequently a user logged in with a given method.
  • Max and Avg Duration ‚Äì high values indicate that sessions are not being closed, either explicitly or by timeout, or that there is real activity on those sessions.

 

Only new users/sessions per minute (configurable).

The chart is also available for any BiWhy table.

Bucket analysis (here session duration) shows that most sessions last about 60 minutes. This indicates that they are being terminated by timeout, meaning users either do not close reports or explicit session termination on tab/browser close is not working. It also means that most of the sessions we see are idle.

The duration line chart visualizes the 60-minute pattern (timeout).

 

Duration Gantt view ‚Äì session dynamics.

 

Admin Page. Analysis & Administration.

If the data element is not release I obtain the error:
Data element ZDE_XCO_TEST_01 does not exist in active version.

        DATA(lo_text_attribute) = xco_cp_data_element=>text_attribute.

        DATA(lo_language) = xco_cp=>language( 'P' ).

        DATA(lo_text_heading) = lo_text_attribute->heading_field_label->create_text(  xco_cp=>string( 'ID' ) ).
        DATA(lo_text_long) = lo_text_attribute->long_field_label->create_text(  xco_cp=>string( 'Identificador' ) ).
        DATA(lo_text_medium) = lo_text_attribute->medium_field_label->create_text(  xco_cp=>string( 'Identificador' ) ).
        DATA(lo_text_short) = lo_text_attribute->short_field_label->create_text(  xco_cp=>string( 'Identif.' ) ).

        DATA(lo_target) = xco_cp_i18n=>target->data_element->object( iv_name = 'ZDE_XCO_TEST_01' ).

        DATA(lo_transport_request) = xco_cp_cts=>transport->for( iv_transport = 'DEVK973218' ).

        " Set the translation.
        lo_target->set_translation(
          it_texts           = VALUE #( ( lo_text_heading ) ( lo_text_long ) ( lo_text_medium ) ( lo_text_short ) )
          io_language        = lo_language
          io_change_scenario = lo_transport_request
        ).


The documentation says:

The entry point for retrieving a collection of objects from the ABAP Repository is XCO_CP_ABAP_REPOSITORY=>OBJECTS. Does anyone know why the XCO requires the object to be released?

entry.title: Re: Validation and set creation
entry.content:
Dear @Andrea_Gr,

How can we define a new custom message for validation rules?

Answer:

  1. Open Fiori app ‚ÄúManage Substitution/Validation Rules‚Äù
  2. Open an existing Validation rule or create a new one.
  3. In General Information:
    • Set Control Level = Error or Warning.
    • Click value help on the Message field.
  4. In the popup:
    • Message ID/number
    • Short text (what user will see)
    • Severity (error/warning)
    • Choose Create
    • Enter:
    • Save.
  5. Back in the rule, select this new message in Message.

Now this custom text will appear when the validation fails.

More details below:

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F4406')/S35

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/e6175604fc874bfe84aa14d2f9ae1fbd/5c8c2825535f4e3aa9b7f716a0085221.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a376cd9ea00d476b96f18dea1247e6a5/ac7785b7870344a8998c8492c0cd5c3d.html

How can we implement a validation: Posting Date must not be greater than Acquisition Date?

Answer:

  1. In the same app Manage Substitution/Validation Rules click Create Rule.
  2. Choose:
    • Business Context (e.g. Journal Entry Item / asset-related context).
    • Rule Type = Validation Rule.
  3. In General Information:
    • Set Control Level = Error.
    • Assign the custom message from point 1.
  4. (Optional) In Precondition, restrict where it runs (company code, doc type, etc.).
  5. In the Validation section, add a condition:
    • Field: Posting Date
    • Operator: Less than or equal to (<=)
    • Value/Field: Acquisition Date

If Posting Date > Acquisition Date -> rule fails -> error message is shown.

       6. Save and Activate the rule.

How can we define Sets (dynamic value lists) and use them in validation rules?

Answer:

  1. Open Manage Substitution/Validation Rules
  2. In any rule (Precondition or Validation), add a new condition line.
  3. Choose a field (e.g. Document Type, Company Code).
  4. Choose operator IN / NOT IN.
  5. Click value help on the Value field.
  6. In the popup:
    • Set ID (e.g. Z_DOC_TYPES_INV)
    • Description
    • Values
    • Switch to Set / Set ID view.
    • Choose Create (new set).
    • Enter:
    • Save.
  7. Back in the condition:
    • Select your Set ID as the value.

More details below from SAP Community and SAP Note:

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/how-to-extend-a-custom-field-and-derive-the-value-using-the-manage/ba-p/13529638

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/how-to-create-sets-for-validation-in-s4-hana-cloud/qaq-p/12696426

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3583820

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: SAP Digital Manufacturing, Manual Setup of OEE with hierarchy.
entry.content:
Currently we are setting up Demos for OEE calculation, this is how far we got:

-Integrating Workcenters and Resources
-Setting up OEE Configuration with Reason Codes for Resources
-Changing Resource Status
-Calculating/Visualizing the OEE based on the availability for a Resource

However with a hierarchical Workcenter Structure in Mind...
1. Level: Production Line A
2. Level                        Line A - Cell A
2. Level                        Line A - Cell B
2. Level                        Line A - Cell C
..it seems like the OEE Configuration is much more complex and not intuitive. 

What we want to achive is to be able to aggregate the Cells, which produce in sequence by Resource Status to the Production Line. Meaning if one Cell is down, the whole line is down. 

However currently we dont see any possible way to integrate or manually create parent/child relationships at Workcenter oder Resource level, and also in the OEE Hierarchy Section of Manage Workcenters we are unable to add any hierarchy since the "Add" button never suggests something to add. 

Is this feature currently disabled?

In the meantime we will try to archieve our use case manually by creating dummy resources that represent the overall production line status.

It would be really helpful to have a blog post regarding the OEE Hierarchy.

entry.title: Print Form Services Credential Migration: We‚Äôre Live and Auto-Provisioning!
entry.content:
Dear customers and partners,

As a sequel to my previous blog announcing this migration here: Simplifying Print Form Services Credentialling - SAP Community

We‚Äôre pleased to announce that our migration of credentials for Print Form Services (PFS) is now fully complete. From this point forward, new PFS credentials will be automatically provisioned ‚Äî you no longer need to request or wait for manual issuance.

What this means for you

  • Seamless credential issuance: New accounts or services will receive PFS credentials automatically.

  • Minimal disruptions: All existing credentials remain valid and unaffected by the migration cut-over.

  • Improved stability and management: The fresh infrastructure delivers higher reliability and simplified administration.

Thank you!
We want to extend our heartfelt thanks to all of our customers and partners for your patience and support during this migration. Your cooperation made it possible for us to deliver this transition with minimal disruption and to enhance our services behind the scenes.

If you have any questions, notice any issues, or need assistance with your PFS credentials, please reach out to our support team and we‚Äôll be glad to help. Thank you for your partnership and for continuing to trust us.

entry.title: Drive more Business Value out of your SAP Public Cloud Solution Subscriptions.
entry.content:
If you are an SAP Public Cloud customer running solutions like SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Ariba, etc., or you are a new SAP Business Suite customer running public cloud packages, I want to make you aware of a great capability included in SAP for Me to help drive more business value out of your SAP subscription.

SAP for Me includes the Customer Insights Dashboard. This tool analyzes the history of your support data, product portfolio, renewals, support contracts, system landscape, cases, and more. Within this dashboard, there is a great section that shows Cloud Functional Usage. In the following blogs below from my SAP colleague Swetlana, you can learn more about how to use this Cloud Functional Usage section in detail. I advise you to review them before you continue so you can follow the example that I will present shortly.

Functional Usage for your Public Cloud Products in Customer Insights reporting in SAP for Me

Functional Usage - Value Drivers and Peer Group Comparison

SAP for Me ‚Äì Customer Insights Dashboard - Cloud Functional Usage

In this blog, I want to use the Cloud Functional Usage Report included in SAP for Me to give you a couple of recommendations to increase your business value from your SAP Public Cloud Subscription by focusing on the Value Drivers and relevant industry peer groups when you run different SAP Public Cloud Applications‚Äîin other words, to bring business value to your entire public cloud landscape.

In the following example below, imagine you are a live SAP customer with a public cloud landscape including subscriptions for: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, some SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Business Data Cloud ‚ÄúSAP BDC‚Äù (including Analytic Cloud and SAP Datasphere), and SAP BTP, or you can have the new SAP Business Suite Public Cloud packages as I discussed before.

Example - Live SAP customer with a public cloud landscape

In this example, you have already followed some of the recommendations provided in my last blog  for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, but now want to focus on increasing business value for the entire public cloud landscape.

First, you need to go to SAP for Me and select the Cloud Functional Usage Report. I suggest you quickly review the Usage History to view your solution capabilities, but I recommend adding the view by Product to make it simpler to identify in your landscape.

SAP for Me ‚Äì Customer Insights Dashboard - Cloud Functional Usage ‚Äì Usage History

With the product view, now you can look at the solution capabilities in your different SAP Product Subscriptions.

Cloud Functional Usage ‚Äì Usage History view by Product

Per Swetlana‚Äôs previous blog explanations, you know that this view shows your current usage by solution capability for each specific subscribed product.

Now that you are looking at your usage, you can see the business impact, so you can now select the ‚ÄúBusiness Value‚Äù tab to focus on the value drivers and relevant industry peer groups. Here, I also recommend that you view the graphic by product.

SAP for Me ‚Äì Customer Insights Dashboard - Cloud Functional Usage ‚Äì Business Value

By doing so, you can now see the top 10 value drivers based on the most used solution capabilities in your landscape.

Cloud Functional Usage ‚Äì Business Value ‚Äì view by Product

You now have a great option to render this graphic by specific value driver(s), by product(s), or by both, which will give you plenty of flexibility to look at business outcomes. Let‚Äôs imagine you want to impact the reduction of finance costs in your organization to make your finance team more productive and cost-effective. You can select that value driver and look at your current usage in your company.

Cloud Functional Usage ‚Äì Business Value ‚Äì filtered by Value Driver ‚ÄúReduce finance cost‚Äù

You can see here that this value driver is impacted by a couple of products including: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Finance), SAP Analytics Cloud (SAP BDC), and Cash & Treasury Add-on (Finance).

You also see that there are plenty of solution capabilities not used (in gray), which you can evaluate to see if you can start using them to help drive more business value. However, what makes this report really useful is that you can look at your usage intensity or lack of usage by comparing it with your relevant industry peer group. This means you can benchmark your usage with your industry peer group to gain some insights on what other SAP customers are doing.

Cloud Functional Usage ‚Äì Business Value ‚Äì selected by non-used solution capabilities in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

In the above example, I selected the 30 non-used solution capabilities in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, as I really want to impact the reduction of financial cost. When doing this, I see that my industry peer group is highly using 9 out of the 30 capabilities, moderately using 4 out of the 30 capabilities, and low using 17 out of the 30 capabilities.

So this helps you benchmark your usage with your industry peer group. Here it will make sense to see what are those 9 capabilities that I can evaluate to implement to help drive more business value. So, if I select the 9 capabilities in the industry footprint graph, I can now see the details below.

Cloud Functional Usage ‚Äì Business Value ‚Äì selected by highly used solution capabilities in relevant industry peer group in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

If I then select the solution capability ‚ÄúFinancial Reporting,‚Äù I get an overview of the functionality on how it contributes to the value driver. I also get additional information, such as the Fiori apps that I can start using or activate to benefit from this functionality.

Solution Capability ‚Äì Financial Reporting

I can then click on all 33 relevant Fiori apps and go to the SAP Fiori Apps Reference Library to see the apps.

SAP Fiori Apps Reference Library filtered by Solution Capability ‚Äì Financial Reporting

From there, I can get all information from the app, such as product information and implementation, and I can then check directly in my system landscape.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition ‚Äì Looking at Fiori App ‚ÄúDisplay Cash Flow ‚Äì Indirect Method‚Äù

I can then go back and look at the other components‚Äîlike the Cash & Treasury Add-on‚Äîand compare them with the relevant industry peer group that I potentially should be considering. I see that the Financial Risk Management (which I don‚Äôt use) solution capability has a higher moderate usage among relevant industry peers, so I should evaluate its applicability.

Cloud Functional Usage ‚Äì Business Value ‚Äì selected by non-used solution capabilities in Cash & Treasury Add-on

I can click again on the solution capability to look at impacts, view the Fiori Application Library, and review the apps in my system as I did before.

Solution Capability ‚Äì Financial Risk Management

This time, instead of looking at each app, I will click on the SAP Fiori Apps grouped by end user role ‚ÄúTreasury Risk Manager‚Äù to see the overall authorization in the SAP Fiori Apps Reference Library.

SAP Fiori Apps Reference Library filtered by Solution Capability ‚Äì Financial Risk Management ‚Äì Treasury Risk Manager Role

You could also look at this using a list view or try the new list view that has significantly improved how information is rendered.

SAP Fiori Apps Reference Library New List View filtered by Solution Capability ‚Äì Financial Risk Management

From here, you can go to your system landscape and then look to include the SAP business role you are not using, ‚ÄúTreasury Risk Manager.‚Äù

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition ‚Äì Activating ‚ÄúTreasury Risk Manager Role‚Äù

Now, let's take a look at SAP SuccessFactors. I go back to the Cloud Functional Usage Report, but this time I will filter by Product.

Cloud Functional Usage ‚Äì Business Value ‚Äì filtered by Product ‚ÄúSAP SuccessFactors‚Äù

Here you can now see the Top 10 value drivers for SAP SuccessFactors. Of course, you can select specific components to evaluate specific areas of improvement.

If I focus now only on SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central, I can see that there are 4 solution capabilities I am not using which have a high impact on many value drivers.

Cloud Functional Usage ‚Äì Business Value ‚Äì selected by non-used solution capabilities in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central

If I am very conservative and only focus on the high usage in the relevant industry peer group, I see that I could impact many value drivers by focusing on ‚ÄúPosition Management‚Äù solution capability.

Cloud Functional Usage ‚Äì Business Value ‚Äì selected by highly used solution capability in relevant industry peer group in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central

Like in the other example, I can click on the solution capability to review the details.

Solution Capability ‚Äì Position Management

And then go to SAP SuccessFactors to activate the solution capability.

SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central ‚Äì Activating Position Management

And start using it in your system.

SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central ‚Äì Using Position Management

I could continue the exploration to the SAP BDC components (SAP Analytics Cloud & SAP DataSphere‚Ä¶ see below and run another cycle as the ones I presented above.

Cloud Functional Usage ‚Äì Business Value ‚Äì filtered by Product ‚ÄúSAP BDC ‚Äì SAP Analytics Cloud & SAP Datasphere‚Äù

I hope this Cloud Functional Usage information included in SAP for ME provides you with some ideas for your new projects, new business rollouts, or new business requirements for your entire public cloud landscape. Keep in mind that solution capabilities are expanding from traditional functional scope to also include SAP Business AI, so SAP will continue to add more in this area. Remember, this is not the only tool that can be used; SAP has other tools such as SAP Signavio, SAP WalkMe, SAP LeanIX, and SAP Cloud ALM that can be used in tandem to help drive more business value from your SAP subscription. I encourage you to discuss these points with your SAP Customer Success Manager, SAP Account Executive, or SAP Partner. They may be able to provide you with additional recommendations and guidance.

Your insights and opinions are valuable, so please don't hesitate to contribute by commenting on this blog.

Follow us via @SAP and #S4HANA or follow @Marco_Valencia (SAP Business Suite Customer Success Management).

entry.title: Re: Onboarding 1.0 Decommissioning Procedure & FAQ
entry.content:
I also want to call out an excellent question that came up this week in discussions with a customer, and one I wanted to note here as well in a comment. Please see my revised blog above.

What happens to my E-Verify Cases through Onboarding 1.0?

While your E-Verify Cases will no longer be accessible through the Onboarding 1.0 interface after decommissioning, you can still export the "E-Verify Summary Form" to have a record of the E-Verify Cases created during Onboarding 1.0's tenure. This Form should be part of your Document Export and Retention functions as part of decommissioning, listed above.

What happens to any outstanding or open E-Verify Cases through Onboarding 1.0, when the product is decommissioned?

There may be some circumstances where there are E-Verify Cases that are still open during Onboarding 1.0's decommissioning and afterwards, and that cannot be acted on as they are pending either government (DHS, SSA, or both) action. For these outstanding E-Verify Cases, please generate a Report within Onboarding 1.0 for these Cases. SAP SuccessFactors, as your E-Verify Web Service Provider, can continue to provide updates to you through a Customer Support Case.

We anticipate this should be a rare situation in the event customers have successfully been able to reduce and migrate their E-Verify activity over to Onboarding or another solution prior to the decommissioning.

entry.title: PLR 2025 - Corre√ß√µes retroativas de imposto
entry.content:
Ol√° pessoal, 

Acabamos de lan√ßar uma solu√ß√£o importante para lidar com o desafio tribut√°rio da Participa√ß√£o nos Lucros e Resultados (PLR) de 2025, permitindo que a folha de pagamento corrija o pagamento de imposto ap√≥s a publica√ß√£o tardia da tabela oficial de impostos pelo Governo Brasileiro. 

Desafio de 2025 

A publica√ß√£o tardia da tabela oficial de impostos do PLR para 2025 trouxe as seguintes consequ√™ncias: 

  • Processamento com Tabela Anterior: Empresas utilizaram a tabela do ano anterior, gerando um c√°lculo de imposto equivocado 
  • Publica√ß√£o Retroativa: A nova tabela foi publicada com validade retroativa 
  • Impacto nos Funcion√°rios: Colaboradores pagaram mais impostos do que o devido 
  • Autoriza√ß√£o Governamental: Governo autorizou empresas a reembolsarem os valores pagos em excesso 

Nossa Solu√ß√£o 

Desenvolvemos uma solu√ß√£o que identifica e corrige retroativamente os impostos sobre PLR pagos em excesso durante 2025. O sistema utiliza novas rubricas para calcular as diferen√ßas e processar os reembolsos devidos aos colaboradores, garantindo conformidade com as autoriza√ß√µes governamentais. 

A solu√ß√£o est√° dispon√≠vel atrav√©s das seguintes SAP Notes: 

  • 3672102 - Retroactive PLR Tax Corrections: Creation of New Wage Types 
  • 3669244 - BRIR - Retroactive PLR Tax Corrections  for 2025
  • 3681233 - eSocial - S-1010 - Adjustments for /IOP and /ROP wage types 

Novas Rubricas 

O sistema introduz tr√™s novas rubricas que trabalham em conjunto: 

  • /IRP - Indicador reembolso PLR: Rubrica adicionada manualmente no infotipo 0015 ‚Äì Pagamento complementar para acionar o c√°lculo retroativo 
  • /IOP - IRRF PLR desc. em excesso: Indica o valor pago em excesso 
  • /ROP - Reembolso IRRF sobre PLR: Reembolso do valor pago em excesso 

Como Funciona 

Acionamento Manual: Para colaboradores que n√£o receber√£o mais pagamentos de PLR em 2025 o acionamento √© manual 

  • Adicione a rubrica /IRP ao √∫ltimo per√≠odo pagamento incorreto no infotipo 0015 
  • Sistema calcular√° automaticamente os valores em excesso 
  • Reembolso ser√° processado na pr√≥xima folha 

Ajuste Autom√°tico: Para funcion√°rios com pagamentos futuros de PLR no ano de 2025, o ajuste √© autom√°tico 

  • Nenhuma a√ß√£o manual necess√°ria 
  • Sistema ajusta automaticamente no pr√≥ximo pagamento de PLR 
  • Ambas as rubricas, /IOP e /ROP, aparecem no mesmo per√≠odo se a compensa√ß√£o for insuficiente 

Transfer√™ncia e PLR em Empresas Anteriores: Para empregados transferidos entre empresas 

  • Adicione /IRP ao √∫ltimo pagamento de PLR de cada empresa afetada 
  • Trate a empresa atual da mesma forma que nos cen√°rios acima 
  • O dinheiro pago em excesso de todos os PLRs calculados de forma incorreta ser√£o reembolsados no pr√≥ximo pagamento 

Considera√ß√µes Importantes 

  • Aplica√ß√£o Espec√≠fica para 2025: Esta solu√ß√£o foi desenvolvida especificamente para lidar com o atraso da tabela de PLR de 2025 
  • C√°lculo Anual: Impostos de PLR s√£o calculados anualmente, considerando todos os pagamentos do ano 
  • Uso Inteligente do Gatilho: Adicione /IRP apenas quando n√£o houver mais pagamentos de PLR esperados 

Com essas atualiza√ß√µes, voc√™ garantir√° que seus sistemas estejam em conformidade com as exig√™ncias governamentais, promovendo efici√™ncia e tratamento justo aos funcion√°rios afetados pela situa√ß√£o excepcional de 2025. 

Gostou desse post? 

D√™ um Like e compartilhe o conte√∫do com seus colegas. 

Fiquem √† vontade para deixar um feedback, coment√°rio ou pergunta sobre este Blog post no espa√ßo abaixo. E n√£o esque√ßam de seguir a tag HCM Payroll Brazil na SAP Community para ficarem ligados nas √∫ltimas not√≠cias. 

Um abra√ßo, 
Ramiro dos Santos Manoel 
Time de HCM Brasil
